SpNote.note:
For broadband L and M imaging use the following exposure times:
Filter Camera Exp,s Obs,s Mode L ' 0.06 0.64 20 512 subarray THERMAL ND* 0.60 25 Full array THERMAL ND* 0.12 0.175 60 Full array THERMAL CDS 0.20 50 Full array THERMAL ND (Linearity is slightly better with THERMAL CDS) M' 0.06 0.4 25 Full array THERMAL CDS or THERMAL ND 0.4 25 512 sub array THERMAL CDS or THERMAL ND 0.12 0.175 50 Full array THERMAL CDS 0.059 90 512 sub array THERMAL CDS 0.08 90 512 sub array THERMAL ND
* you may also use thermal CDS with lower exposure time
L and M standards must be observed with identical readout area, offsets and exp time as the target due to non-linearity effects
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note: We have found that the central 100 pixel wide area of the array, and the low QE bottom right quadrant of the array, do not always subtract cleanly in the thermal. The offset patterns are designed to avoid these areas as far as possible. For the subarray and the nod8 pattern this means using the left (N) side of the array only.
SpNote.title: Offset patterns

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.
SpNote.title: Standards

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the L' filter with the 0.12"/pixel camera and full 1024x1024 readout.
Select camera or pixel scale from the camera drop down menu.
Select broad or narrowband filter and your choice from the drop down menu. Exposure time and readmode will reset when you change filter!
Readout area is selected from the read mode drop down menu e.g. NDSTARE 1024x1024 or NDSTARE 512x512.
Be careful changing exposure time as the read mode will reset! Refer to the web pages for optimum exposure times in the thermal.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: If you want to do aperture photometry select NOD_SELF_FLAT_NO_MASK_APHOT
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UIST configuration above, then you must change it for the dark too. The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure times for your source and dark are matched.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the nod/jitter pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one nod/jitter set

SpNote.note: The offsets place a set of four observations in each of the top right and lower left quadrants. The lower throughput lower right is avoided. Offsets from center are large enough to avoid sometimes poorly behaved central 100 pixels.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

SpNote.note:
Exec for making a map of a large source, < 2 arcmin. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of positions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 150 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un guided"
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
For larger targets see also "extended_5x5".
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_3x3_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region(s), which default to approximately 210 arcseconds north-west and south-east of the target. If there is any doubt concerning the uniformity of the sky, it is better to restrict yourself to one sky region, so that changes in sky level can be measured, and not be attributed to a sky offset between regions. See the IRCAM3 equivalent of this observation for a template.
The target offsets are displaced to give 50% overlap; larger offsets resulting in less than 50% overlap may result in striping in the final mosaic due to different noise levels in the overlap regions.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.

SpNote.note:
Basic Idea: =======
With Coronographic imaging, the user may use either a 6-pixel (0.7arcsec) or an 11-pixel (1.3 arcsec) wire. These are suspended 1/4 and 3/4 of the way along a 120"x20" rectangular aperture (needed for coronagraphic polarimetry). The posn angle can be used to orientate the source so that extended objects are perpendicular to the wire; e.g. a disk orientated E-W should use a Posn-angle of 0 degs, while a disk orientated N-S should use a posn angle of -90 degs. Any angle between -90 and +90 degrees can be used, although angles between -90 and 0 degrees make acquisition a little easier. If you don't care about the angle, PLEASE USE -90 DEGREES.
By default the acquisition process described below will put the source behind the 6-pixel wire. If the wider occultor is required, all offsets should have a p value of -62.6 arcsec (this being the distance between the two wires); note, offsets in q are along the wire, which is ~20" in length..
Imaging acquisition: ============
In the UIST component below, set the instrument for coronagraphic imaging (coron mask, filter, full array, NDSTARE, etc.) but SELECT A SHORT EXPOSURE TIME for imaging acquisition (1sec for bright stars/point sources). The exposure time to be used for the actual coronagraphic imaging will be set in the "UIST Imaging" iterator further down the sequence.
At the telescope UIST will be set for coronagraphic observations with your chosen posn angles BUT it will have a short exposure time. At the break in the sequence, the observer runs Movie, acquires the target as if he/she were doing spectroscopy (i.e. using Gaia - pick object and UPICK on the TCS) , then continues the sequence. Immediately after acquisition the exposure time/coadds are increased for the actual coronagraphic observations.
SpNote.title: HOW TO DO CORONAGRAPHIC IMAGING

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Make sure the coronograph is selected and the exposure time is short (1sec usually) for IMAGING ACQUISITION.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note: At the time of writing there was no dedicated pipeline recipe for coronographic imaging. Please see the UIST web pages, or contact your support scientist, for updates.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe selection

SpNote.note: The 0,0 offset below is a trick we use to set-up imaging acquisition. You will acquire the target at the break immediately after this "offset".
SpNote.title: Dummy offset for acquisition

SpNote.note: The dark below provides a frame for dark-subtraction. It should have the same exposure time as used in the "UIST Imaging" iterator below, so DON'T click on "set default"
SpNote.title: Darks

SpNote.note: The iterator below sets the exposure time for the coronagraphic imaging. These will be longer than the 1 or 2 secs used for the acquisition process above. 10-20 secs are recomended for 7-9th mag point sources and moderate seeing (0.6-0.7 arcsec).
SpNote.title: UIST iterator

SpNote.note:
These offsets nod the source between the wire and postions behind the mask or off the array. The latter are used as "sky frames"; they are used to construct a flat-field. The object is also nudged slightly up and down the wire to correct for bad pixels.
19 frames in all give 10 on sky and 9 with the source behind the wire. Fewer offsets could also be used, e.g. 6 on sky and 5 on source. In both cases, the seqeunce starts and end on sky.
NOTE: Offsets in q move move along the wire, regardless of posn angle. An offset of q= +24 would put the target midway between the two rectangular apertures in the coronographic mask. An offset of q= +48 would put the star in the top aperture; for bright sources this is obviously NOT recommended.
SpNote.title: offsets

SpNote.note:
Use this observation to make some observations of blank sky which can be processed to generate flat fields. The reduction recipe makes a flat that other reduction recipes can use.
To make more efficient use of telescope time instead of obtaining a flat this way igenerate a flat from an observation of a relatively faint and isolated target.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Choose the appropriate filter and set the exposure time to be at least equal to the background limit time given on the web page
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: This recipe generates a flat field that can be used by other data-reduction recipes. It masks residual stars to reduce artifacts and biases in the flat. If you do not want masking select recipe SKY_FLAT for object observation in the DRRecipe component below.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UFTI component then change it for the dark here.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time. Click the reset-to-default button to ensure that your dark exposure time matches that set above.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: This last offset is to send the telescope back to 0,0 after the observing is finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note:
Observing Point Sources ==============
There are two MSBs for observing Point Sources; one assumes that the science target is a bright point source which the DR can "find" in the reduced spectral image and display. The second assumes that the science target is faint. In this case, the DR will find the rows containing the standard star and assume that the science target lies on the same rows. These rows will be extracted and displayed. Please bear this in mind when acquiring targets - the standard star and science target should be positioned on the same row AND column (same x-y pixel in imaging acquisition) if the science target is faint.
In both cases, the source is nodded up and down the slit.
Observing Extended Sources =================
"Extended sources nod to sky" is the default for observing large extended objects. Here, the slit is nodded completely off source so that the target is only on the slit in 50% of the frames.
If, however, the science target is only marginally extended then consider using one of the "extended source slide along slit" MSBs, which are essentially the same as the point source MSB, except that a much larger slide (and a different DR recipe) is used. Slides of up to +30" and -30" are possible.
Slitless Spectroscopy =============
This mode is also now available, although we have very little experience with this type of spectroscopy. In the UIST component, under slit mask, users should select "small field". This will give a 60x60 arcsec aperture on the sky. The image plane can be rotated so that dispersed spectra do not overlap on the array (using the Pos. angle). See the UIST web pages for further details, or contact Chris Davis (c.davis@jach.hawaii.edu).
SpNote.title: Which MSB should I use??

SpNote.note:
For bright calibrators exposures of a few seconds work well.
For faint targets the following exposures are recommended with the 4 pixel slit:
240s for all grisms except - 60s for shortL 20s for longL 6s for M
IMPORTANT - 240 sec is the maximum exposure time possible with UIST
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note:
All targets (bright standards and faint sources) are now acquired in imaging mode. Simply make sure that each observation contains an acquisition Eyeball (see the examples below).
Note: use short exposures and coadds for faint sources, rather than one very long exposure. This is to avoid (1) saturating on the sky, and (2) residual signal in spectra from the bright sky background encountered during acquisition.
SpNote.title: Acquisition

SpNote.note:
WHICH SLIT SHOULD I USE? ---------------------- Because of internal focus limitations, we have had to install seperate slits for IJ and JH grism spectroscopy. You should find that you can ONLY use the 2_pix_wide_120s and 4_pix_wide_120s slits with the IJ and JH grisms. The other slits (1_pix_wide_120, 2_pix_wide_120 and 4_pix_wide_120) should be used with ALL OTHER grisms.
Bottom line - the OT will NOT allow you to make an incorrect selection.
Note that the wider 5-pixel and 7-pixel slits can be used with ALL grisms (IJ, JH, HK, short-J, long-J, etc...)
POSITION ANGLES ---------------- The default slit PA is -90 so that it matches the UIST imaging orientation (it makes imaging acquisition a bit simpler!), though any angle, between -90 and +90 (measured E of N) can be used.
SpNote.title: Important info. about SLITS

SpNote.note:
Please note -
If you change ANYTHING in the UIST component (grism, position angle, etc.) then you MUST click on the flat and arc "eyeball" and click on "set default".
Otherwise the flat and arc observation WON'T pick up the change!!!
SpNote.title: IMPORTANT - Flats and Arcs

Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with an east-west 4 pixel slit. Select grism, angle and slit from the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: This flat and arc observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above. In other words, the telescope will slew to the standard, where you can then do the flat and arc before observing the standard itself.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough.
Note about the standard: ================
Chances are, the bright standard will be too bright for imaging acquisition (it may leave a latent image on the array after imaging acquisition). To get around this the TSS will in actual fact acquire a nearby 9-10 mag star. Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star down the UIST slit. THIS IS WHY THE BRIGHTESTS SELECTABLE SOURCE MAG FOR TARGET ACQUISITION IS 9TH. SO CHOOSE 9-10 FOR YOUR STANDARD.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note: Offsets are both positive - these will move the target into the top half of the array, where the QE (sensitivity) of the array is better.
SpNote.title: Offsetting

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness).
- For bright sources: 1 coadd x 1 sec should be enough. - For faint sources: 2,3 or 4 coadds x 5 sec is usually ok. - In the L and M bands: 4 or 5 coadds x 1-2 sec is good.
See the UIST Spectroscopy web pages on Target Acquisition if you're not sure! Acquisition on point sources down to about 17th mag is possible.
NOTE: Its better to use a few coadds and short exposures than one long exposure for imaging acquisition!!
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note: Offsets are both positive - these will move the target into the top half of the array, where the QE (sensitivity) of the array is better.

SpNote.note:
FLUSH ARRAY DARKS - ARE THEY NECESSARY??
After imaging acquisition, a bright target and/or the bright sky background in the HKLM bands may leave residual signal on the array, at the 1% level. This signal will appear in the first few spectroscopy frames and may introduce extra noise for low-background and faint target spectroscopy (though the DC signal at least should "subtract-off" with sky subtraction).
This signal (and its associated noise) will be weak, particularly if you've used coadds and short exposures rather than one long exposure for imaging acquisition (recommended for faint targets or for thermal spectroscopy). HENCE, FOR MOST PEOPLE THIS WILL NOT BE A PROBLEM AND THE DARKS ON THE NEXT LINE SHOULD BE DELETED - highlight the eyeball and click on "Cut".
However, for moderate resolution (short-/long-) spectroscopy in the HKLM bands on very faint targets (>16th mag, say), the additional noise from the residual signal may be an issue. In this case, use the five short darks in the next line to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken. The overhead associated with this flushing is about 25-30 seconds (for five 3sec darks).
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1 or a few seconds is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (OPTIONAL)

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).

Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.

SpNote.note:
Observing Extended Sources: =================
"IFU nod to blank sky" is the default for observing small, extended objects. Here, the 3.3"x6.0" IFU field-of-view is nodded completely off source so that the target is only on the IFU in 50% of the frames. The sequence simply nods back and forth between 0,0 and blank sky. This is the simplest mode with the IFU.
"IFU, nod to blank sky with jitters" is a variant of the above. Here the frames taken on the target are jittered slightly to fill in bad pixels. THIS MODE IS RECOMMENDED FOR SMALL TARGETS THAT DON'T OVERFILL THE IFU 3.3"x6.0" FIELD-OF-VIEW.
"IFU map extended source" demonstrates how the IFU may be used to map across a more extended target, i.e. one that is larger than the IFU field-of-view.
SpNote.title: Which MSB should I use (IFU)??

SpNote.note:
For bright calibrators exposures of a few seconds work well.
For faint targets the following exposures are recommended with the 4 pixel slit:
240s for all grisms except - 60s for shortL 20s for longL 6s for M
IMPORTANT - 240 sec is the maximum exposure time possible with UIST
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note: The default IFU PA is -90 so that it matches the UIST imaging orientation (it makes imaging acquisition a bit simpler!), though any angle, between -90 and +90 (measured E of N) can be used.
SpNote.title: IFU long-axis position angle

SpNote.note:
All targets (bright standards and faint sources) are now acquired in imaging mode. Simply make sure that each observation contains an acquisition Eyeball (see the examples below).
Note: use short exposures and coadds for faint sources, rather than one very long exposure. This is to avoid (1) saturating on the sky, and (2) residual signal from the bright sky background appearing in your IFU spectral images.

To offset the effect this artifact may have on your data, use the darks below to "flush" the array. The overhead associated with this flushing is about 10-15 seconds (for five 1sec darks).
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1 or a few seconds is best for flushing...

Chances are, the bright standard will be too bright for imaging acquisition (it may leave a latent image on the array after imaging acquisition). To get around this the TSS will in actual fact acquire a nearby 9-10 mag star. Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star on the IFU THIS IS WHY THE BRIGHTESTS SELECTABLE SOURCE MAG FOR TARGET ACQUISITION IS 9TH. SO CHOOSE 9-10 FOR YOUR STANDARD.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
FLUSH ARRAY DARKS - ARE THEY NECESSARY??
After imaging acquisition for the standard you will probably see a weak, residual image of the star on subsequent frames, at the 1% level. This signal will appear in the first few IFU spectroscopy frames and may "overlap" spectra from the standard star (though it should to some extent "subtract-off" with sky subtraction). To offset the effect this artifact may have on your data, use the darks below to "flush" the array. The overhead associated with this flushing is about 10-15 seconds (for five 1sec darks).
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1 or a few seconds is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (RECOMMENDED)

SpNote.note:
Please use "Object" and "Sky" observes (eyes) for the object and blank-sky exposures, so that the DR pipeline can reduce the data. Note below that 2 observations are taken at the sky offset position.
Note: p and q are perpendicular to and along the IFU long axis.
SpNote.title: IFU offsets

SpObs.title: Science target -- nod to blank sky with jitter

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness).
- For bright sources: 1 coadd x 1 sec should be enough. - For faint sources: 2,3 or 4 coadds x 5 sec is usually ok. - In the L and M bands: 4 or 5 coadds x 1-2 sec is good.
See the UIST IFU web pages on Target Acquisition if you're not sure! Acquisition on point sources down to about 17th mag is possible.
NOTE: Its better to use a few coadds and short exposures than one long exposure for imaging acquisition!!
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
FLUSH ARRAY DARKS - ARE THEY NECESSARY??
After imaging acquisition, a bright target and/or the bright sky background in the HKLM bands may leave residual signal on the array, at the 1% level. This signal will appear in the first few spectroscopy frames and may introduce extra noise for low-background and faint target spectroscopy (though the DC signal at least should "subtract-off" with sky subtraction).
This signal (and its associated noise) will be weak, particularly if you've used coadds and short exposures rather than one long exposure for imaging acquisition (recommended for faint targets or for thermal spectroscopy). HENCE, FOR MANY PEOPLE THIS WILL NOT BE A PROBLEM AND THE DARKS ON THE NEXT LINE SHOULD BE DELETED - highlight the eyeball and click on "Cut".
However, for IFU spectroscopy in the HKLM bands on very faint targets (>16th mag, say), the additional noise from the residual signal may be an issue. In this case, use the five short darks in the next line to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken. The overhead associated with this flushing is about 25-30 seconds (for five 3sec darks).
NB - don't click on default in the darks - a few seconds is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (OPTIONAL)

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuration set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, ifu angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note:
The idea here is that the frames on the target are jittered slightly up and down the long (6.0") axis of the IFU. This is to fill in bad pixels. This should give slightly cleaner data than the simple "nod to blank sky" sequence, which simply nods back and forth between 0,0 and blank sky, without any offsetting when on the target.
Note that the pixel scale is 0.12" along the long (q) axis of the IFU - so jitters should be multiples of 0.12". Small jitters are recommended, since bigger jitters will give a smaller overlap in the final data.
Jitters in p are possible, although the width of the IFU field-of-view is much smaller in this axis (only 3.3").
Note that this mode uses the MAP_EXTENDED_SOURCE recipe to reduce the data, rather than the EXTENDED_SOURCE recipe. This is so that the sky-subtracted data on the source are correctly mosaicked in the data cube.
One object or one sky exposure is taken at each offset position.
p is perpendicular to the IFU long axis; q is along the long axis.
SpNote.title: IFU offsets

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with the IFU orientated E-W. Select grism, angle, etc. the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: This flat and arc observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above. In other words, the telescope will slew to the standard, where you can then do the flat and arc before observing the standard itself.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note:
In this example the final IFU field will be roughly 10" long and 3.3" wide; the object frames are offset up and down the IFU long axis (q).
To map larger areas, simply add additional offset iterators (use the copy and paste buttons). Keep to the sequence object-sky-sky-object -- object-sky-sky-object...etc., with the offsets for the objects chosen so as to map your source.
One object or one sky exposure is taken at each offset position.
NB: p is perpendicular to the IFU long axis, q is along the long axis. the pixel scale in p is 0.24arcesc, in q it is 0.12"
SpNote.title: IFU offsets
